Putting it all together.

Now, putting all parts into a single C program.

The overall steps are:

Read N and M.

Read M edges (each line has three numbers, but only first two are used).

Compute the number of connected components (ans).

Convert ans to string s1.

Process s1 through the second part's algorithm to get r.

Convert r to string s2.

Process s2 through third part's checks, output "Yes" or "No".

Now, the code structure:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

#define MAX_N 100000 // assuming N is up to 1e5, but need to see.

// But in C, for variable-length arrays, we can read N first.

int main() {

    // First part: read N, M, edges, compute ans.

    int N, M;

    scanf("%d %d", &N, &M);

    // Read edges and build adjacency lists.

    // Using linked lists for adjacency lists.

    // Define structure for linked list nodes.

    struct Node {
        int val;
        struct Node *next;
    };

    struct Node **adj = (struct Node **)malloc(N * sizeof(struct Node *));
    for (int i=0; i<N; i++) adj[i] = NULL;

    for (int i=0; i<M; i++) {

        int X, Y, Z;

        scanf("%d %d %d", &X, &Y, &Z);

        X--; Y--; // convert to 0-based.

        // Add Y to adj[X]

        struct Node *new_node = (struct Node*)malloc(sizeof(struct Node));

        new_node->val = Y;

        new_node->next = adj[X];

        adj[X] = new_node;

        // Add X to adj[Y]

        new_node = (struct Node*)malloc(sizeof(struct Node));

        new_node->val = X;

        new_node->next = adj[Y];

        adj[Y] = new_node;

    }

    // BFS to count connected components.

    int visited[N]; // assuming C99 for VLA.

    memset(visited, 0, N * sizeof(int));

    int ans =0;

    for (int i=0; i<N; i++) {

        if (!visited[i]) {

            ans++;

            // BFS queue.

            int queue[N]; // assuming N is manageable.

            int front=0, rear=0;

            queue[rear++] =i;

            visited[i] =1;

            while (front < rear) {

                int current = queue[front++];

                struct Node *temp = adj[current];

                while (temp != NULL) {

                    int neighbor = temp->val;

                    if (!visited[neighbor]) {

                        visited[neighbor] =1;

                        queue[rear++] = neighbor;

                    }

                    temp = temp->next;

                }

            }

        }

    }

    // Now, ans is computed. Convert to string s1.

    char s1[20];

    sprintf(s1, "%d", ans);

    // Second part processing.

    int l =2019;

    int m[l];

    for (int i=0; i<l; i++) m[i]=0;

    m[0] =1;

    int a=0, r=0;

    int len = strlen(s1);

    int pow_10 =1;

    for (int i=0; i < len; i++) {

        char c = s1[ (len-1) -i ];

        int digit = c - '0';

        int term = (digit * pow_10) % l;

        a = (a + term) % l;

        int mod = a % l;

        r += m[mod];

        m[mod] +=1;

        pow_10 = (pow_10 *10) % l;

    }

    // Now, r is computed. Convert to string s2.

    char s2[20];

    sprintf(s2, "%d", r);

    // Third part processing.

    int len2 = strlen(s2);

    if (len2 !=4) {

        printf("No\n");

        return 0;

    }

    int count[10] = {0};

    for (int i=0; i<4; i++) {

        char c = s2[i];

        count[c - '0']++;

    }

    int two_count =0;

    for (int i=0; i<10; i++) {

        if (count[i] ==2) two_count++;

        else if (count[i] !=0) {

            two_count = -1; // invalid

            break;

        }

    }

    if (two_count ==2) {

        printf("Yes\n");

    } else {

        printf("No\n");

    }

    // Free allocated memory for adjacency lists.

    for (int i=0; i<N; i++) {

        struct Node *current = adj[i];

        while (current != NULL) {

            struct Node *next = current->next;

            free(current);

            current = next;

        }

    }

    free(adj);

    return 0;

}
